repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Emergency Reconstruction and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Emergency
            Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Project for Sri Lanka was
            marginally satisfactory. The project achieved some of its
            objectives, its impact on institutional development was
            negligible, sustainability is unlikely, and the performance
            of both the Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, it is
            recommended that more effective institutional arrangements
            for project implementation and monitoring are established.
            Second, there is a need to ensure that continuous monitoring
            and feedback influences project attributes in order to adapt
            to changing ground conditions. Finally, it is important to
            build sufficient capacity in traditional institutions early
            on to enable their meaningful participation in formulating
            and appraising the project.

display_title.display_title:
Sri Lanka - Emergency

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Emergency Reconstruction and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Reconstruction and
            Rehabilitation Project aims to deliver immediate assistance
            to the Government of Sri Lanka (GOSL) to assist returnees,
            revive economic activities and restore essential services
            that will facilitate the reconstruction and rehabilitation
            process in areas throughout Sri Lanka affected by the
            strife. To that end, the project includes components that
            (a) will help promote economic activities and hence provide
            employment opportunities; and (b) infrastructure that will
            facilitate economic and social activities and accelerate
            return to normalcy.  Specifically, the project includes (i)
            site preparation, (ii) shelter, (iii) assistance to
            industry, (iv) infrastructure, (v) telecommunications and
            (vi) technical assistance.
